content.text:
# Timeline of the 2025 Pacific hurricane season

The 2025 Pacific hurricane season is the current tropical cyclone season in the Pacific Ocean east of the International Date Line (IDL) in the Northern Hemisphere. It officially began on May 15 in the eastern Pacific (east of 140°W), and on June 1 in the central Pacific (from the IDL east to 140°W); it will end in both on November 30. These dates, adopted by convention, historically describe the period in each year when most tropical cyclogenesis occurs in these regions of the Pacific. The season's first system, Tropical Storm Alvin, developed on May 28.
This timeline documents tropical cyclone formations, strengthening, weakening, landfalls, extratropical transitions, and dissipations during the season. It includes information that was not released throughout the season, meaning that data from post-storm reviews by the National Hurricane Center, such as a storm that was not initially warned upon, has been included.
By convention, meteorologists use one time zone when issuing forecasts and making observations: Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), and also use the 24-hour clock (where 00:00 = midnight UTC). Tropical cyclone advisories in the Eastern North Pacific basin use both UTC and the nautical time zone where the center of the tropical cyclone is currently located. Time zones utilized (east to west) are: Central, Mountain, Pacific and Hawaii. In this timeline, all information is listed by UTC first, with the respective regional time zone included in parentheses. Additionally, figures for maximum sustained winds and position estimates are rounded to the nearest 5 units (knots, miles, or kilometers), following National Hurricane Center practice. Direct wind observations are rounded to the nearest whole number. Atmospheric pressures are listed to the nearest millibar and nearest hundredth of an inch of mercury.
__TOC__
Timeline
May
May 15
* The Eastern Pacific hurricane season officially begins.
May 28
* 18:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Depression OneE forms from a large disturbance along the eastern North Pacific monsoon trough, about  southwest of Acapulco, Guerrero.
May 29
* 12:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression OneE strengthens into Tropical Storm Alvin.
*18:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Alvin attains its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of .
May 31
* 06:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. MST, May 30) at Tropical Storm Alvin degenerates into a remnant low, and later dissipates.
June
June 1
* The Central Pacific hurricane season officially begins.
June 8
* 06:00 UTC (00:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Barbara forms from a disturbance along the eastern North Pacific monsoon trough, about  offshore the coast of Guerrero.
* 06:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. MST, June 7) at Tropical Depression ThreeE forms from a broad area of low pressure located within the eastern North Pacific monsoon trough.
* 12:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression ThreeE strengthens into Tropical Storm Cosme.
June 9
* 06:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. MST, June 8) at Tropical Storm Barbara strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane and simultaneously attains its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of .
* 18:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Cosme attains its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of .
June 10
* 00:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. MST June 9) at Hurricane Barbara weakens to a tropical storm.
* 18:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Barbara degenerates to a remnant low, and later dissipates.
June 11
* 06:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. MST, June 10) at Tropical Storm Cosme degenerates to a remnant low, and later dissipates.|group="nb"}}
* 18:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Four-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Dalila about 195 mi (315 km) south of Zihuatanejo.
June 14
* 18:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Dalila reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 170 mi (280 km) south-southwest of Manzanillo, Colima.
June 16
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST June 15) at Tropical Storm Dalila transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 320 mi (515 km) west of Manzanillo.
June 17
* 03:00 UTC (9:00 p.m. CST June 16) at Tropical Depression Five-E forms about 535 mi (860 km) southeast of Punta Maldonado, Guerrero.|group="nb"}}
* 09:00 UTC (3:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Five-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Erick about 450 mi (725 km) southeast of Punta Maldonado.
June 18
* 12:00 UTC (6:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Erick strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 160 mi (255 km) south-southeast of Puerto Ángel, Oaxaca.
* 18:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CST) at Hurricane Erick intensifies to Category 2 strength about 105 mi (165 km) south of Puerto Ángel.
June 19
* 00:00 UTC (6:00 p.m. CST June 18) at Hurricane Erick intensifies to Category 3 strength about 55 mi (90 km) south-southwest of Puerto Ángel.
* 05:40 UTC (11:40 p.m. CST June 18)Hurricane Erick intensifies into a Category 4 hurricane.
* 06:00 UTC (12:00 a.m. CST) at Hurricane Erick reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 70 mi (110 km) west-southwest of Puerto Ángel.
* 12:00 UTC (6:00 a.m. CST) at Hurricane Erick weakens to Category 3 strength and simultaneously makes landfall in extreme western Oaxaca with sustained winds of , about 20 mi (30 km) east of Punta Maldonado, Guerrero.
* 15:00 UTC (9:00 a.m. CST) at Hurricane Erick rapidly weakens to Category 1 strength inland, about 30 mi (50 km) north-northwest of Punta Maldonado.
* 21:00 UTC (3:00 p.m. CST) at Hurricane Erick weakens to a tropical storm inland, about 35 mi (60 km) north-northeast of Acapulco, Guerrero.
June 20
* 00:00 UTC (6:00 p.m. CST, June 19) at Tropical Storm Erick weakens to a tropical depression inland, about 60 mi (95 km) north-northwest of Acapulco.
* 03:00 UTC (9:00 p.m. CST, June 19) at Tropical Depression Erick decays to an area of low pressure inland, about 95 mi (155 km) northwest of Acapulco.
June 29
* 09:00 UTC (3:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Six-E forms about 270 mi (435 km) south of Acapulco, Guerrero.
* 15:00 UTC (9:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Six-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Flossie about 240 mi (390 km) south of Acapulco.
July
July 1
* 03:00 UTC (9:00 p.m. CST June 30) at Tropical Storm Flossie strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 175 mi (280 km) south of Manzanillo, Colima.
* 15:00 UTC (9:00 a.m. CST) at Hurricane Flossie intensifies to Category 2 strength about 150 mi (245 km) southwest of Manzanillo.
July 2
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST July 1) at Hurricane Flossie intensifies to Category 3 strength and simultaneously reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 210 mi (340 km) west-southwest of Manzanillo.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Flossie weakens to Category 2 strength about 275 mi (445 km) south-southeast of Cabo San Lucas, Baja California Sur.
July 3
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST July 2) at Hurricane Flossie weakens to Category 1 strength about 215 mi (345 km) south of Cabo San Lucas.
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Flossie weakens to a tropical storm about 205 mi (330 km) south-southwest of Cabo San Lucas.
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Flossie transitions to a post-tropical cyclone about 200 mi (320 km) southwest of Cabo San Lucas.
July 27
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, July 26) at Tropical Depression One-C forms about 1,085 mi (1,745 km) southeast of Honolulu, Hawaii.
July 28
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST July 27) at Tropical Depression One-C strengthens into Tropical Storm Iona about 960 mi (1,545 km) southeast of Honolulu.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Iona strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 895 mi (1,440 km) southeast of Honolulu.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Depression Two-C forms about 1,140 mi (1,840 km) east-southeast of Honolulu, Hawaii.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Depression Two-C strengthens into Tropical Storm Keli about 1,090 mi (1,755 km) southeast of Honolulu.
July 29
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST July 28) at Hurricane Iona rapidly intensifies to Category 4 strength about 790 mi (1,270 km) south-southeast of Honolulu.
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST July 28) at Tropical Storm Keli reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 960 mi (1,550 km) southeast of Honolulu.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Iona reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 765 mi (1,230 km) south-southeast of Honolulu.
July 30
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST July 29) at Hurricane Iona weakens to Category 2 strength about 690 mi (1,115 km) south of Honolulu.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Iona weakens to Category 1 strength about 695 mi (1,115 km) south-southwest of Honolulu.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Iona weakens to a tropical storm about 730 mi (1,180 km) south-southwest of Honolulu.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Keli opens into a trough about 520 mi (835 km) south of Honolulu.
July 31
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST July 30) at Tropical Storm Gil forms about 785 mi (1,260 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August
August 2
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST, August 1) at Tropical Storm Iona weakens to a tropical depression and simultaneously crosses the International Date Line, exiting the Central Pacific basin, about 1,465 mi (2,355 km) west of Honolulu.
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST, August 1) at Tropical Storm Gil strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane and simultaneously reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 1,080 mi (1,740 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Gil weakens to a tropical storm about 1,250 mi (2,010 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 3
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Gil transitions to a post-tropical cyclone about 1,660 mi (2,670 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 4
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, August 3) at Tropical Depression Eight-E forms about 835 mi (1,345 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Depression Eight-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Henriette about 895 mi (1,440 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 5
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST, August 4) at Tropical Storm Henriette reaches its initial peak intensity with sustained winds of  and a central pressure of , about 940 mi (1,510 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 6
* 21:00 UTC (3:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Ivo forms about 195 mi (310 km) south-southeast of Acapulco.
August 8
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Henriette degenerates into a remnant low about 785 mi (1,265 km) east of Hilo, Hawaii.
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Ivo reaches its peak intensity with winds of 65 mph (100 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 999 mbar (29.50 inHg), about 190 mi (310 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 9
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, August 8) at The remnants of Tropical Storm Henriette regenerate into a tropical depression about 615 mi (985 km) east of Hilo.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Depression Henriette restrengthens into a tropical storm about 485 mi (780 km) east-northeast of Hilo.
August 10
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Henriette strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 445 mi (720 km) north-northeast of Hilo.
August 11
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. PDT, August 10) at Tropical Storm Ivo weakens into a tropical depression about 510 mi (825 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Henriette reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 525 mi (845 km) north of Honolulu.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Depression Ivo transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 615 mi (990 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 12
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Henriette weakens into a tropical storm about 825 mi (1,335 km) north-northwest of Honolulu.
August 13
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, August 12) at Tropical Storm Henriette transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 1,160 mi (1,865 km) north-northwest of Honolulu.
August 24
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Depression Ten-E forms about 475 mi (765 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 25
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression Ten-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Juliette about 440 mi (705 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 26
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Juliette reaches its peak intensity with winds of  and a minimum central pressure of , about 360 mi (580 km) west of Socorro Island.
August 28
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Juliette transitions to a post-tropical cyclone about 710 mi (1,140 km) west-northwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
August 31
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, August 30) at Tropical Depression Eleven-E forms about 1,000 mi (1,610 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Depression Eleven-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Kiko about 1,045 mi (1,680 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September
September 2
* 03:00 UTC (9:00 p.m. CST, September 1) at Tropical Depression Twelve-E forms about 145 mi (230 km) south-southwest of Manzanillo.
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, September 1) at Tropical Storm Kiko strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 1,840 mi (2,965 km) east of Hilo.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression Twelve-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Lorena about 240 mi (385 km) west of Manzanillo and about 345 mi (550 km) south-southeast of Cabo San Lucas.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko intensifies into a Category 2 hurricane about 1,775 mi (2,855 km) east of Hilo.
September 3
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Lorena strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 120 mi (195 km) south-southwest of Cabo San Lucas and about 275 mi (445 km) south-southeast of Cabo San Lazaro, Baja California Sur.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko intensifies into a Category 4 hurricane about 1,600 mi (2,580 km) east of Hilo.
September 4
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST, September 3) at Hurricane Kiko reaches its peak intensity with winds of 145 mph (230 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 945 mbar (27.91 inHg), about 1,560 mi (2,510 km) east-southeast of Hilo.
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST, September 3) at Hurricane Lorena reaches its peak intensity with winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 981 mbar (28.97 inHg), about 110 mi (180 km) south-southwest of Cabo San Lazaro and about 210 mi (340 km) west of Cabo San Lucas.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Lorena weakens into a tropical storm about 125 mi (205 km) west-southwest of Cabo San Lazaro.
September 5
* 03:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. HST, September 4) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a Category 3 hurricane about 1,360 mi (2,190 km) east-southeast of Hilo and about 1,565 mi (2,520 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Lorena transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 170 mi (275 km) west of Cabo San Lazaro.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko re-intensifies into a Category 4 hurricane about 1,195 mi (1,925 km) east-southeast of Hilo and about 1,400 mi (2,255 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
September 6
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a Category 3 hurricane about 935 mi (1,500 km) east-southeast of Hilo and about 1,135 mi (1,830 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
September 7
* 01:30 UTC (3:30 p.m. HST, September 6) at Hurricane Kiko re-intensifies into a Category 4 hurricane about 895 mi (1,440 km) east-southeast of Hilo and about 1,100 mi (1,770 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, September 6) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a Category 3 hurricane about 785 mi (1,265 km) east of Hilo and about 990 mi (1,590 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
* 21:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a Category 2 hurricane about 635 mi (1,025 km) east of Hilo and about 835 mi (1,345 km) east-southeast of Honolulu.
September 8
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a Category 1 hurricane about 410 mi (660 km) east of Hilo and about 590 mi (950 km) east of Honolulu.
September 9
* 09:00 UTC (11:00 p.m. HST, September 8) at Hurricane Kiko weakens into a tropical storm about 245 mi (395 km) northeast of Hilo and about 375 mi (605 km) east of Honolulu.
September 10
* 15:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. HST) at Tropical Storm Kiko transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 110 mi (180 km) north of Honolulu.
September 11
* 21:00 UTC (3:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Thirteen-E forms about 120 mi (195 km) southeast of Acapulco.
September 12
* 15:00 UTC (9:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Thirteen-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Mario and simultaneously reaches its initial peak intensity with speeds of 40 mph (65 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 1006 mbar (29.71 inHg), about 40 mi (65 km) south-southwest of Zihuatanejo and about 60 mi (95 km) south-southeast of Lazaro Cardenas, Michoacán.
September 13
* 05:30 UTC (11:30 p.m. CST, September 12) at Tropical Storm Mario degenerates to a remnant low about 85 mi (135 km) southwest of Manzanillo.
September 14
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at The remnants of Tropical Storm Mario regenerate into a tropical storm about 55 mi (90 km) east-southeast of Socorro Island and about 305 mi (490 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 15
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Mario reaches its peak intensity with winds of 65 mph (100 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 993 mbar (29.33 inHg) about 260 mi (420 km) west-northwest of Socorro Island and about 325 mi (520 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 16
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Mario weakens into a tropical depression about 495 mi (800 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 17
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. PDT, September 16) at Tropical Depression Mario transitions into a post-tropical cyclone about 535 mi (860 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 21
* 21:00 UTC (3:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Narda forms about 240 mi (390 km) south-southeast of Zihautanejo.
September 23
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Narda strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 295 mi (475 km) southwest of Manzanillo.
September 24
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST, September 23) at Hurricane Narda intensifies into a Category 2 hurricane about 525 mi (845 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Narda reaches its peak intensity with winds of 105 mph (165 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 970 mbar (28.65 inHg), about 540 mi (870 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 25
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST, September 24) at Hurricane Narda weakens into a Category 1 hurricane about 580 mi (935 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 28
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. PDT, September 27) at Hurricane Narda weakens into a tropical storm about 1,070 mi (1,725 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 29
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. PDT, September 28) at Tropical Storm Narda degenerates to a remnant low about 985 mi (1,580 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
September 30
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression Fifteen-E forms about 955 mi (1,540 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Depression Fifteen-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Octave about 930 mi (1,495 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October
October 4
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Priscilla forms about 285 mi (460 km) south-southwest of Manzanillo and about 555 mi (890 km) south-southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 5
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Octave strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 1,025 mi (1,650 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Priscilla strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 290 mi (470 km) south-southwest of Cabo Corrientes and about 485 mi (780 km) south-southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 6
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. PDT) at Hurricane Octave reaches its peak intensity with winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 984 mbar (29.06 inHg), about 950 mi (1,530 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. PDT) at Hurricane Octave weakens into a tropical storm about 920 mi (1,480 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 7
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Priscilla intensifies into a Category 2 hurricane about 255 mi (410 km) west-southwest of Cabo Corrientes and about 245 mi (390 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. MST) at Hurricane Priscilla reaches its peak intensity with winds of 110 mph (175 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 958 mbar (28.29 inHg), about 330 mi (535 km) west of Cabo Corrientes and about 215 mi (345 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 8
* 12:00 UTC (5:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Priscilla weakens into a Category 1 hurricane about 195 mi (310 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 18:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. MST) at Hurricane Priscilla weakens into a tropical storm about 195 mi (315 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 9
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m  MST) at Tropical Storm Octave transitions into a post-tropical cyclone 360 mi (580 km) south of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (9:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Seventeen-E forms about 115 mi (185 km) south-southeast of Zihuatanejo and about 750 mi (1,210 km) southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 18:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CST) at Tropical Depression Seventeen-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Raymond about 115 mi (190 km) south-southeast of Zihuatanejo and about 745 mi (1,200 km) southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 10
* 09:00 UTC (3:00 a.m. CST) at Tropical Storm Raymond reaches its peak intensity with winds of 60 mph (95 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 998 mbar (29.47 inHg), about 120 mi (195 km) west of Zihuatanejo and about 565 mi (915 km) southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Priscilla degenerates into a remnant low about 220 mi (355 km) west-northwest of Cabo San Lazaro.
October 11
* 18:00 UTC (11:00 a.m. MST) at Tropical Storm Raymond weakens into a tropical depression about 85 mi (135 km) south-southeast of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 12
* 03:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. MST, October 11) at Tropical Depression Raymond degenerates into a remnant low about 5 mi (10 km) west of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 24
* 21:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. PDT) at Tropical Depression Eighteen-E forms about 780 mi (1,255 km) south-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 25
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Depression Eighteen-E strengthens into Tropical Storm Sonia about 835 mi (1,340 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
* 15:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Sonia reaches its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 1001 mbar (29.56 inHg), about 840 mi (1355 km) southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
October 29
* 09:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. PDT) at Tropical Storm Sonia degenerates into a post-tropical remnant low about 1,180 mi (1,895 km) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula.
November
November 30
* The 2025 Pacific hurricane season officially ends in the Eastern and Central Pacific basins.
